library-metadata.title: Interactive Differential Equations
library-metadata.subtitle: A Step-by-Step Approach to Methods & Modeling
library-metadata.blurb: This interactive online text is intended to be used to learn the introductory concepts of ordinary differential equations. The book is designed for students who have completed single-variable calculus and is suitable for a one semester course in differential equations. The book is written in a straightforward, readable style and has a large number of worked examples and exercises.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.1.1 Differential equations differ from standard equations in that they have .

li.div: a solution
Incorrect. While this statement is generally true, it is not what makes it different from any other equation.
a \(y\) variable
Incorrect. Any equation could contain a \(y\) variable.
an unknown
Incorrect. Most equations contain an unknown.
a derivative
Correct! If an equation contains a derivative, it is a differential equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.1.2 Which of the following best describes a differential equation?

li.div: An equation involving only algebraic expressions.
An equation involving functions and their derivatives.
An equation involving trigonometric functions.
An equation that changes over time.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.1.3 What distinguishes a differential equation from a standard equation?

li.div: It contains an unknown variable.

ul.li: Incorrect. Both standard and differential equations contain unknown variables.

li.div: It contains a derivative.

ul.li: Correct! A differential equation contains one or more derivatives, which differentiates it from a standard equation.

li.div: It contains a \(y\) variable.

ul.li: Incorrect. Any equation could contain a \(y\) variable.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.1 An equation that contains an "=" sign and at least one derivative is called a derivative equation.

ul.li: True

li.div: Incorrect, derivative equation is not a standard term in mathematics.

ul.li: False

li.div: Correct!

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.2 The expression \(z^{(18)}\) is the same as \(z\) to the power of 18.

ul.li: True

li.div: Incorrect. Please read the note on derivative notation.

ul.li: False

li.div: Correct!

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.3 Identify the differential equation.

li.div: Correct! This equation involves a derivative, making it a differential equation.
Incorrect. This equation does not contain any derivatives, so it is not a differential equation.
Incorrect. This equation does not contain any derivatives, so it is not a differential equation.
Incorrect. This equation does not contain any derivatives, so it is not a differential equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.4 In this textbook, what does the abbreviation "DE" stand for?

li.div: An Ordinary Differential Equation
Correct! In this book, DE is shorthand for Differential Equation.
An Partial Differential Equation
Incorrect! Please review the note “Convention: DE means ODE”.
Dependent Equation
Incorrect. While DE could theoretically stand for Dependent Equation, in this book it always refers to Differential Equation.
Derivative Equation
Incorrect. While DE could theoretically stand for Derivative Equation, is not a standard term in mathematics. In this book it always refers to Differential Equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.5 What distinguishes an ordinary differential equation (ODE) from a partial differential equation (PDE)?

li.div: The number of variables the unknown function depends on.
Correct! An ODE has derivatives with respect to a single variable, while a PDE involves multiple variables.
The number of derivatives in the equation.
Incorrect. Please review the definition of ODEs and PDEs.
The number of solutions the equation has.
Incorrect. Please review the definition of ODEs and PDEs.
The number of hours it takes to solve the equation.
Incorrect. Please review the definition of ODEs and PDEs.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.6 Which of the following is NOT required for an equation to be classified as a differential equation?

li.div: An unknown function.
Incorrect. A differential equation does include an unknown function, which we are solving for.
An \(x\)-variable.
Correct! An \(x\)-variable is not a requirement for a differential equation.
A derivative.
Incorrect. The presence of at least one derivative is essential to define a differential equation.
An "=" sign.
Incorrect. An equality sign is required for an equation to be classified as a differential equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.7 What notation will this textbook primarily use for derivatives?

li.div: Both prime and Leibniz notation.
Correct! The textbook will use both prime and Leibniz notation for derivatives.
Only prime notation.
Incorrect. While prime notation will be used, Leibniz notation will also be utilized.
Only Leibniz notation.
Incorrect. The book will use both Leibniz and prime notation for derivatives.
Subscript notation.
Incorrect. Subscript notation is not used for derivatives in this textbook.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.2.8 Click on all the Differential Equations.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.3.1 Which variable in \(\ds (1 - x)y'' - 4xy' + 5y = \cos x \) is the independent variable?

li.div: Yes! \(x\) is the independent variable.
Incorrect. Review the examples.
Incorrect. Review the examples.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.3.2 Which variable in \(\ds \frac{dy}{dx} + 2y = 3x^2 \) is the dependent variable?

li.div: Incorrect. \(\frac{dy}{dx}\) represents the derivative of the dependent variable with respect to the independent variable.

ul.li: Incorrect. The dependent variable is the one being differentiated.
Correct! \(y\) is the dependent variable in this equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.3.3 In a differential equation, the dependent variable has a derivative applied to it.

ul.li: True

li.div: Correct! The dependent variable in a differential equation always has a derivative applied to it.

ul.li: False

li.div: Incorrect. By definition, a differential equation involves derivatives of the dependent variable.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.3.4 Which variable in \(\ds \frac{dP}{ds} + \frac{P}{s^2} = 17s \) are we solving for?

li.div: dependent variable, \(s\)
Incorrect. \(s\) is neither the dependent variable, nor what we are solving for.
independent variable, \(s\)
Incorrect! \(s\) is the independent variable, but it is not what we are solving for.
dependent variable, \(P\)
Yes! We are solving for the unknown, \(P\text{.}\)
independent variable, \(P\)
Incorrect. We are solving for \(P\text{,}\) but it is not the independent variable.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.1 Given \(\ds 5y'' + 2y' - \cos(t) y = 7\text{,}\) what is the coefficient of \(\ds y'\text{?}\)

ul.li: Incorrect. \(5\) is the coefficient of \(y''\text{.}\)
Correct! \(2\) is the coefficient of the term involving \(y'\text{.}\)
Incorrect. \(\cos(t)\) is the coefficient of \(y\text{.}\)
Incorrect. \(7\) is the constant on the right-hand side of the equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.2 Given \(\ds 3t^2 y' + \frac{1}{t} y - 4 = 0\text{,}\) which of the following is considered a constant term?

ul.li: Incorrect. This term contains a derivative of the dependent variable \(y\text{,}\) so it is not a constant term.
Incorrect. This term involves the dependent variable \(y\text{,}\) so it is not a constant term.
Correct! \(-4\) is the constant term because it does not depend on the dependent variable \(y\) or its derivatives.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.3 \(3t\) is an example of a constant term.

ul.li: True
Correct! In the context of differential equations, \(3t\) is a constant term since it is not multiplied by the dependent variable \(y\) or one of its derivatives.
False
Incorrect. While \(3t\) is not a constant function, it is a constant term in the context of differential equations.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.4 \(y\) is the coefficient of the term \(y \sin(t)\).

ul.li: True
Incorrect. The coefficient is the factor multiplying the entire term involving the dependent variable, not the dependent variable itself.
False
Correct! The coefficient is what multiplies the term involving the dependent variable, so in this case, the coefficient of \(y \sin(t)\) is \(\sin(t)\text{,}\) not \(y\text{.}\)

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.5 The term \(y'''\) does not have a coefficient.

ul.li: True
Incorrect. Every term in a differential equation has a coefficient, even if that coefficient is simply 1.
False
Correct! The coefficient of \(y'''\) is 1, even if it is not explicitly written.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.6 Given \(\ds e^t y''' + 4y' - 3y = \sin(t)\text{,}\) which terms has a function as its coefficient?

ul.li: Correct! \(e^t\) is a function of \(t\) and acts as the coefficient of \(y'''\text{.}\)
Incorrect. \(4\) is a constant coefficient, not a function.
Incorrect. \(-3\) is a constant coefficient, not a function.
Incorrect. \(\sin(t)\) is on the right-hand side of the equation and is not acting as a coefficient for any term.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.7 Given \(\ds t^3 y'' + 6 y' - \ln(t) y = 0\text{,}\) which statement best describes the coefficient of \(y\text{?}\)

ul.li: It is a constant coefficient
Incorrect. A constant coefficient does not depend on the independent variable.
It is a function of the independent variable
Correct! The coefficient \(\ln(t)\) depends on the independent variable \(t\text{.}\)
There is no coefficient
Incorrect. The term \(\ln(t) y\) has a coefficient, which is \(\ln(t)\text{.}\)
It is an arbitrary constant
Incorrect. \(\ln(t)\) is a specific function of \(t\text{,}\) not an arbitrary constant.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.8 Given \(\frac{d^2y}{dt^2} - 3t^2 y' + 4y = 0\text{,}\) which of the following statements is true?

ul.li: The coefficient of \(y'\) is \(-3t^2\text{.}\)
Correct! The term \(-3t^2 y'\) has a coefficient of \(-3t^2\text{.}\)
The coefficient of \(y\) is \(-4\text{.}\)
Incorrect. The coefficient of \(y\) is \(4\text{,}\) not \(-4\text{.}\)
The coefficient of \(y'\) is \(-3t\text{.}\)
Incorrect. The correct coefficient of \(y'\) is \(-3t^2\text{,}\) not \(-3t\text{.}\)
There is no constant term in the equation.
Correct! The equation does not include a constant term since all terms involve the dependent variable or its derivatives.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.4.9 Select all the coefficients in the differential equation.

span.div: The coefficients in this equation are \(t^2\text{,}\) \(4\text{,}\) and \(t\text{.}\) Remember, coefficients are the factors multiplied by the dependent variable or its derivatives.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.5.1 Which of the following equations is a third-order differential equation?

ul.li: Correct! The highest derivative here is the third derivative, making it a third-order differential equation.
Incorrect. This is a second-order differential equation.
Incorrect. This is a second-order differential equation.
Incorrect. This is a first-order differential equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.5.2 The order of a differential equation is determined by the number of terms it contains.

ul.li: True
Incorrect. The order is based on the highest derivative, regardless of the number of terms.
False
Correct! The order is determined by the highest derivative, not the number of terms.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.5.3 The differential equation \(\ds (1 - x)y'' - x^4y' + y^5 = \cos x \) has order .
Reading Question 1.1.5.4 The differential equation \(\ds y''' + 3y' - 4y = 0 \) has order .
Reading Question 1.1.5.5 The differential equation \(\ds t^3 \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + \frac{d^5y}{dt^5} = \sin(t) \) has order .
Reading Question 1.1.6.1 \(3t\) is a linear term.

ul.li: True
Correct! The term \(3t\) is linear because it is a function of the independent variable only.
False
Incorrect, review the examples of linear terms in the section on Linear Terms.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.2 \(y \sin(t)\) is a linear term.

ul.li: True
Correct! The term \(\sin(t)y\) is linear.
False
Incorrect! The term \(\sin(t)y\) is indeed linear.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.3 \(t\sin(y')\) is a linear term.

ul.li: True
Incorrect, review the rules for identifying nonlinear terms.
False
Correct! A term that includes the derivative of the dependent variable inside another function is nonlinear.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.4 \(e^{ty}\) is a linear term.

ul.li: False
Correct! The term \(e^{ty}\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable \(y\) is inside an exponential function.
True
Incorrect. Review the rules for identifying nonlinear terms.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.5 Identify the linear term in the equation: \(\ds\frac{1}{t}y'' + y^2 + \ln(y') = e^t\).

ul.li: Correct! The term \(\frac{1}{t}y''\) is linear because it involves a single derivative of the dependent variable.
Incorrect. This term is nonlinear.
Incorrect. This term is nonlinear because it involves the dependent variable inside a logarithmic function.
Correct! This term is linear because it involves the independent variable only.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.6 Which of the following is a nonlinear term?

ul.li: Incorrect. This is a linear term.
Correct! The term \(t\sin(y')\) is nonlinear because it involves a derivative inside a trigonometric function.
Incorrect. This is a linear term.
Incorrect. This is a linear term.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.7 A linear term can contain the dependent variable multiplied by the independent variable.

ul.li: True
Correct! For example, \(t y\) is a linear term.
False
Incorrect. Carefully review the examples above.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.8 Which of the following terms is linear?

ul.li: Incorrect. \(y^2\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable is raised to a power other than one.
Correct! \(\sin(t)y'\) is linear because it is a function of the independent variable multiplied by the first derivative of the dependent variable.
Incorrect. \(\ln(y)\) is nonlinear because it includes the dependent variable inside another function.
Incorrect. \(y \cdot y'\) is nonlinear because it involves the product of the dependent variable and its derivative.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.9 Which of the following terms is linear?

ul.li: Correct! \(\frac{1}{t}y''\) is linear because it is a function of the independent variable multiplied by the second derivative of the dependent variable.
Incorrect. \(y^3\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable is raised to a power other than one.
Incorrect. \(e^t y^2\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable is squared.
Incorrect. \(y \cdot \cos(y)\) is nonlinear because it involves the product of the dependent variable and a function of the dependent variable.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.10 Which of the following is a characteristic of a nonlinear term?

ul.li: It involves the dependent variable raised to the first power.
Incorrect. This is a characteristic of a linear term.
It involves the dependent variable only as a constant.
Incorrect. This is a characteristic of a linear term.
It includes the dependent variable inside another function.
Correct! A nonlinear term includes the dependent variable inside another function.
It involves the independent variable only.
Incorrect. This is a characteristic of a linear term.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.11 Which term is an example of a nonlinear term?

ul.li: Incorrect. \(3\) is linear because it is a constant.
Incorrect. \(3t\) is linear because it is a function of the independent variable only.
Correct! \(y^2\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable is squared.
Incorrect. \(2t^2 y\) is linear because it is a function of the independent variable multiplied by the dependent variable.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.12 Select the Linear Terms.

span.div: Click on all of the linear terms in the following differential equation.
In this equation, \(\frac{d^2y}{dt^2}\text{,}\) \(t^2 y\text{,}\) \(\sin(t) y'\text{,}\) and \(3t\) are linear terms.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.6.13 Select the Nonlinear Terms.

span.div: Click on all of the nonlinear terms in the following differential equation.
In this equation, \(y^3\) and \(\ln(y)\) are nonlinear terms.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.1 The differential equation \(\frac{dy}{dt} + t^2 y = e^t\) is linear.

ul.li: True
Correct! This equation is linear as all terms involving \(y\) and its derivatives appear to the first power, and there are no nonlinear functions of \(y\text{.}\)
False
Incorrect. This equation is indeed linear because both \(y\) and \(\frac{dy}{dt}\) are to the first power and are not inside any nonlinear functions.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.2 The differential equation, \(\ds y'' + y' \cos t = 7y \text{,}\) is .

ul.li: Linear

li.div: Yes! This DE is linear. Each term involving \(y\) or its derivatives, such as \(y''\text{,}\) \(y' \cos t\text{,}\) and \(7y\text{,}\) is linear. A linear differential equation contains terms where the dependent variable and its derivatives appear to the first power and are not multiplied by each other.

ul.li: Nonlinear

li.div: No, this is linear. Looking carefully at each term, we see:
Since every term is linear, this differential equation is linear. Review the definition of linear differential equations.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.3 The differential equation, \(\ds y'' + \sin(y) = 17t \text{,}\) is .

ul.li: Linear

li.div: No, this is nonlinear. Looking carefully at each term, we see:
Since one term is not linear, this differential equation is nonlinear. Revisit the rules for linearity and nonlinearity.

ul.li: Nonlinear

li.div: Yes! This DE is nonlinear since the \(\sin(y)\) term is not linear. Nonlinear terms involve functions like sine, logarithms, or powers greater than one when applied to the dependent variable \(y\text{.}\)

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.4 The differential equation, \(\ds \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} + e^x = 0 \text{,}\) is .

ul.li: Linear
Incorrect. The term \(e^x\) makes this equation nonlinear, as it involves the exponential function of the dependent variable.
Nonlinear
Correct! The term \(e^x\) introduces nonlinearity into the equation, as it involves the dependent variable \(x\) inside an exponential function.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.5 Select the linear differential equation.

ul.li: Incorrect. The term \(y^3\) makes this equation nonlinear.
Incorrect. The term \(\cos(y)\) makes this equation nonlinear.
Correct! All terms are linear in this equation, making it a linear differential equation.
Incorrect. The term \(y^2\) introduces nonlinearity in this equation.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.6 Which term makes the equation \(\ds y''' + 3y' \sin(t) + y^2 = 0\) nonlinear?

ul.li: Correct! The term \(y^2\) is nonlinear because the dependent variable \(y\) is raised to the second power.
Incorrect. While this term includes a function of \(t\text{,}\) it is still linear because \(y'\) appears to the first power.
Incorrect. The term \(y'''\) is linear because \(y\) and its derivatives are to the first power.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.7 Select all the linear differential equations.

span.div: Linear equations only involve the dependent variable and its derivatives to the first power, and they won’t be inside nonlinear functions like sine or multiplied by each other.

question.label: Reading Question 1.1.7.8 Select all the nonlinear differential equations.

span.div: Click on all of the linear differential equations.

Nonlinear equations often have terms where the dependent variable or its derivatives are raised to powers other than one, or are inside functions like sine, logarithms, or are multiplied by each other.
